bottlenecks.Bottleneck Description: Social bottlenecks from outside the longevity community
General public is generally unaware of or misonfirmed about the science, tech and future possibilities.
Focus on age-related diseases rather than their root cause (aging).
Public skepticism with good cause, history of charlatanism, snake oil, ineffective "anti-aging" treatments.
Lack of mandate, interest and even obstruction by gov agencies, academia, media, healthcare orgs, etc.
Stigma, "pro-aging trance", naturalistic fallacy, culture of dystopianism / tech skepticism.
Apathy, laziness, or bystander effect (failure to take responsibility / thinking someone else will solve it).
Preferencial amplification of negative sentiments, which become the default public opinion by osmosis.
How we dysfunction as a community
More focus on empirical data collection: Multio-omics, images, phenotypes, medical, longititual, clinical, etc.
Ad-hoc data/protocols (not reproducible or comparable) prevents integration and building on prior results.
Isolated people/projects/subdisciplines, need for more networking and connection.
Lack of collective actions such as consensus building, validation, data sharing, standards, roadmapping, etc.
Lack of a consensus definition of aging.
Hype cycles + herd mentality = inefficient distro of resources, short term booms and busts of interest/funding.
Activity is heavily concentrated in a small number of extremely expensive places.
System incentivizes sloppy research and doesn't penalize poor quality.
Aging/longevity has been an insulated backwater - need to emerge, mature and engage with other fields.
Academic grant, IP, and publication systems can over-incentivize competition/secrecy over collaboration.
Sticking to worn out hypotheses / following authority after they are past their prime (ex. beta amyloid)
System dis-incentivize negative result reporting. Results in duplicated efforts, and rewards hype.
Hard learn / track of all the activity, regulations, systems at R&D, translation, clinical and healthcare levels.
Narrow/reductionist "piecemeal" studies fail to address the complexity of aging.
Bright scienetific minds are frequently being wasted on administrative burdens instead of doing science.
Obvious and unnecessary barrier to the spread of scientific information.
Over-focus on "low hanging fruit" that is also low-impact. Starves high impact projects of resources.
Areas that need more basic scientific research.
Lack of a validated way to measure biological age independent of chronological age / lifespan.
Characterization of what changes with age at the molecular/cellular/tissue/physiology levels.
Lack of longitudinal data and samples (clinical records, biomarkers, multi-omics, biobanks).
Complexity of aging is too much for traditional tools and institutional structures to grapple with effectively.
Need for more studies on intra & inter-species longevity variability and intervention responses.
Assorted other science bottlenecks / under-appreciated areas
Need for more systems/network approach studyies of aging.
Every other part could potentially be replaced, therefore brain aging is critical to understand.
Belief that we don't yet understand what aging is, need to determine the fundamental mechanisms.
Learn how to grow and replace any/all biological parts
We need Apollo program levels of funding - measured in % of GDP not in $Bs
Difficult to get new/ambitious ideas funded, institutional culture of risk-aversion and incrementalism.
Longevity/aging is only 0.5% of NIH budget, even smaller elsewhere.
Lifespan studies in the most relevant models take longer than standard grant cycles.
Longevity Biotech is only 1% of total Biotech Market Cap, huge room for growth.
Hard to get funds if you're not from a top institution / company
Not enough funding for translating basic research results to real world applications.
Easier to get grants for continued work vs new directions. Incentives to stay the course even if not promising.
Funding for media and outreach to engage, educate, and attract the public and other communities.
Clinical and longitudinal studies are bureaucratically difficult, expensive, and hard to get funded.
High bureaucracy doesn’t improve decision making, it just wastes people’s time.
Not enough people working in or entering the field.
Lack of education and career paths by existing institutions.
Need to pay people more to make careers in our field sustainable, and to compete for top talent.
Biology has been a "soft/artisinal" science - need to grow up, accelerate the shift to quantitative approaches.
Top talent can have outsized effects, and is currently not focused on longevity.
Immigration/border restrictions are hampering efficient allocaiton of human resources.
Hiring people is time consuming and error-prone.
Need more interdisciplinary overlaps for fresh perspective.
Not enough Tools and Technology development in general.
Current molel organisms are poorly predictive of results in humans.
Animal model studies are slow and expensive.

bottlenecks.Q2 Bottleneck: [X1.3] Lack of In Silico/Systems Aging Models
bottlenecks.Bottleneck Description: More complex/comprehensive computer models describing or predicting the processes of aging.
Lack of accessible and comprehensive data sets.
Access to human samples (healthy, aged, diseased, with good sample info) is difficult, slow and expensive.
Access aged animals and their tissues/cells is difficult, slow and expensive.
Lab tech is expensive, difficult to use, often unreliable. Better/cheaper/new HW enables progress.
Lab automation is expensive and not user friendly - better tech would improve research throughput & quality
Research software is expensive, proprietary, buggy and not user friendly.
Need improvements in toxicity, biodistribution, payload size, immunogenicity, transfection efficiency & more.
Lab space is expensive, scarce, difficult to access.
Maybe humans can't parse bio, need AI to accelerate progress
Cars have hundreds of sensors. Most people have none. They need to be cheaper, non-invasive, easier to use.
Current options are expensive, siloed, difficult to use, disconnected from research.
More compute power unlocks new research capabilities. Also needs to be accessible.
Too many papers for a human to read/parse even if you spend all day every day.
No current regulatory path for aging interventions / longevity medicine.
Lack of translation of basic research results into actual therapies.
Clinical trials (as currently practiced) are slow and expensive.
Risk aversion / harmful action reduction mindset ignores the harm of inaction / slowed progress.
"Sick-care" system maximizes money spent not health/lifespan outcomes, needs structural redesign.
Recruit participants to trials and clinical studies is slow, expensive, bureaocratic.
Pervasive hyped therapies with little to no evidence (NAD, MSCs, diets, hot/cold therapy, light therapy, etc.)

solutions.Solution Description: Social projects aimed outside of the longevity community
Shift public sentiment towards pro-longevity. Cascading benefits (policy, funding, market, career choice...)
Bring fresh persepctives and skillsets into the longevity movement.
Only 1% of Biotech/Pharma is longevity/aging oriented, lots of room for growth.
Deflect career paths at the highest leverage point.
Engage/infiltrate to improve alignment. They have the power to break many bottlenecks if aligned.
A widespread pro-longevity cultural movement.
Regulations/policies to incentivize longevity practices/industry growth - works for climate why not longevity?
For scientists, engineers, operators in longevity - training to communicate clearly and effectively to the public.
How we could improve functioning of the community
More focus on empirical data collection: Multio-omics, images, phenotypes, medical, longititual, clinical, etc.
Set and update standards for data and protocols, incentivize their use.
Mechanism to connect employers, entrepreneurs, investors, volunteers, etc.
Large collaborative projects and rather than ego/grant/publication driven competition.
Organize to facilitate consensus building, validation, data sharing, standards, roadmapping, etc.
Reach a consensus theory/definition of aging
More dedicated aging/longevity research centers. Diverse locations. Varied specialties. Facilitate large projects.
Funded centers dedicated to reproducing / testing the robustness of key results.
Overview of all proposals, projects, pathways, targets, pre and in-clinic pipelines. Linked to data.
Longevity CROs/Cores - make outsourcing research easier such as lifespan studies, multi-omic analysis.
Mechanism to incentivize/enable reporting negative results. Pre-results publication approvals for example.
Make data, samples, results open and available by default.
More focus on long term research and technology paths with higher-impact potential (vs "low hanging fruit")
Reduce/limit the amount of time spent on non-research activities (admin, grants, etc.)
Bold and ambitious, yet free of ego/hype and relatable. Leadership is lacking but necessary to build a movement.
Research goals, that if achieved would unlock progress.
Validated way to measure biological age independent of chronological age / lifespan.
Comprehensive characterization of aging at the molecular/cellular/tissue/physiology levels.
Unlock or generate more longitudinal data and samples (clinical records, biomarkers, multi-omics, biobanks)
Comprehensive map of Intra and inter species aging variation (omics, physiology, phenotype, etc.)
Ambitious and broad range of R&D on brain rejuvenation/replacement.
Methods to grow and replace any/all biological parts
We need Apollo program levels of funding - measured in % of GDP not in $Bs
More ambitious/exploratory projects are needed to accelerate progress.
Longevity/aging is only 0.5% of NIH budget, even smaller elsewhere.
Longer bets on people and projects are necessary for many aging research directions.
Longevity Biotech is only 1% of total Biotech Market Cap, huge room for growth.
Take more bets on system outsiders (non-academic / non-ivy league).
Not enough funding for translating basic research results to real world applications.
Grants for promising people to transition from other fields/areas.
Funding for media and outreach to engage, educate, and attract the public and other communities.
Clinical and longitudinal studies are bureaucratically difficult, expensive, and hard to get funded.
High bureaucracy doesn’t improve decision making, it just wastes people’s time.
Not enough people working in or entering the field.
Need to recruit or train more people in quantitative skills (math, physics, statistics, ml, comp/systems bio)
Need to pay people more to make careers in our field sustainable, and to compete for top talent.
We need edu/career paths for people to start or shift careers in longevity biotech.
Better alternatives to degrees/resumes/interviews? Get people to work faster and more efficiently.
Need more interdisciplinary overlaps for fresh perspective.
Immigration/border restrictions are hampering efficient allocaiton of human resources.
Misc personal solutions
Top talent can have outsized effects, and is currently not focused on longevity.
More Tools and Technology development in general.
Computational/Systems Bio Modeling. Make predictions in silico to save time and cost in meatspace.
Cell/tissue/organ based aging models that are predicitive, affordable and accessible.
Improve robustnest of results by using multiple models.
Better model systems for aging (unspecified how)
Develop longer lived animal models - more likely to be more translatable to human biology.
Skip animals and their problems - develop human model systems (cell, tissue, organ, body, in vivo)
Accelerated aging models could speed progress... if they are representative of normal aging.
Accessible and comprehensive data sets can lift all boats, accelerate progress.
Cheaper/better/new tools to measure biology/health/age would enable more and new studies.
Easy, inexpensive, and well documented samples.
Easy, inexpensive, and well documented aged animals and samples.
Better/easier lab automation would enable increased throughput, higher quality, standards, collaboration.
Better/easier research software would enable increased throughput, higher quality, standards, collaborations.
Better delivery and gene editing tools
Overcome the limits of human intelligence by building better/specialized AI systems.
Cars have hundreds of sensors. Most people have none. They need to be cheaper, non-invasive, easier to use.
Tools to engineer cells, tissues, organs to meet our specifications.
More compute power unlocks new research capabilities. Also needs to be accessible.
Platform for individuals to easily analyze and share health and medical data for advancing research.
A regulatory path for aging interventions / longevity medicine.
Database/marketplace to streamline sourcing clinical research participants.
Allow people to opt-out of medical regulations. A healthcare socioeconomic free zone.
More intervention testing, including combination therapies.
Innovation centers and funding to close the translation gap.
Require trials to make health claims in supplements, lifestyle, etc. Opportunity to design/test lower cost trials?
No current mechanism to test interventions when a therapy isn't IP protectable / highly profitable
How can we make them bigger/better/cheaper and longevity oriented.
Change policies to unlock siloed health/medical data. Require accessibility, standards and interoperability.
Alternative to "sick-care" standards, to help create a market for longevity medicine.
